name: Hans Albers
comments: Actor and singer and the biggest male movie star in Germany between 1930 and 1945 and one of the most popular German actors of the twentieth century. When the Nazis came to power in 1933 Albers and his Jewish girlfriend Hansi Burg moved to Starnberger See in Bavaria. While Albers himself never showed public support for the Nazi regime he became the most popular actor under Nazi rule. The actor nevertheless avoided an overly close association in public. As the ultimate sign of his popularity, the Nazis even silently accepted his relationship with Hansi Burg for a long time, who went to Switzerland and then to Great Britain in 1939, but they secretly remained a couple with him even managing to send her financial support. They were reunited after the war, when she returned to Germany in a British uniform. After the war he never again enjoyed the huge stardom of the 1930s and early 1940s.

Being  Jewish he had to leave Germany in 1935 after losing his work permit and  moved to France, where he lived illegally during World War II.  After the war he became a French citizen.

name: Ben Berlin
comments: Pianist born into a Jewish, German-speaking family in Estonia.  Berlin was classically trained as a pianist, including studies from 1913 through 1919 at the St. Petersburg Conservatory, then the capitol of Russia.  In 1921, Berlin returned to Estonia, but in 1926, he moved to Berlin to expand his  opportunities in music.  He achieved some fame playing in jazz orchestras.  In 1933, after the Nazis came to power, Berlin emigrated to Paris, and then to London.  Berlin continued playing music after he left Germany, but never achieved the popularity he had had in Germany.  Berlin was only 48 years of age when he died.

name: The Fantastic Baggys
comments: Surf and hot rod group, created by P.F. Sloan and Steve Barri. They released one album and three singles between 1964 and 1965. Unsuccessful and soon forgotten in the United States, their songs were surprise hits in South Africa, so that Teal Records and Dunhill , who owned the brand name of The Fantastic Baggys, created a South African version of the group. Two more albums were issued in South Africa between 1966 and 1967, featuring songs from both the originals Baggys and the South African impersonators. According to Sloan, "I had written a letter to the South African Fantastic Baggys asking them if they would like any help with what they were doing, but Dunhill forbade me to have any contact with them at all."
